general_query_list.query: What’s the summary of the meeting?
tokenized_answer: The focus of the meeting was on a presentation of the work done already on the building of the Bayes-net.
The complete prototype of the Bayes-net will be presented in the next meeting.
After that, it will be possible to define interfaces and a dummy construction parser, in order to test and link modules together.

specific_query_list.query: What was the structure of the Bayes-net discussed.
tokenized_answer: The input layer deriving information from things like the user and situation models, feeds into a set of decision nodes, such as the Enter/View/Approach (EVA) endpoint.
In any particular situation, most of the outputs will not be relevant to the given context.
Therefore, they will either have to be pruned a posteriori, or only a subset of the possible decision nodes will be computed in each occasion.

specific_query_list.query: What was discussed about contextualizing output?
tokenized_answer: Due to most outputs not being relevant to the given context, they will either have to be pruned a posteriori, or only a subset of the possible decision nodes will be computed in each occasion.
The latter option could follow a binary search-tree approach and it could also be better in computational terms.
In any case, on what basis the "winner" output is chosen is not clear.

specific_query_list.query: How does the bayes-net deal with inputs?
tokenized_answer: The presented Bayes-net takes inputs from the Situation, User, Discourse and Ontology models.
There are several values (elements) defined in each of these models.
The inputs are fed into the belief-net, which, in turn, outputs the posterior probabilities for the values of all the decision nodes.
At this stage, all the decision nodes are evenly weighted: regardless of the context, each output is trusted equally.
Input and output node structure was presented in XML, as this is the format that will be used for the system.
A large number of the value probabilities have already been set.
